description: The war and its divisive effects on the U.S. never left him. In fact, he left the U.S. and lived in Japan for nearly 20 years because of it. The most lucrative, far-reaching American contacts he made were in the-then exploding U.S.- Asia grain trade.
text:
Every Memorial Day, my longtime friend David would honor both his family and
fellow Vietnam War veterans with a visit to his hometown cemetery, an hour's
drive west of St. Louis.

With the help of siblings and cousins, David would mow the grass in the family
plot, scrub its granite and brass grave markers, and place colorful, fist-
sized peonies on the graves of those he knew and those he didn't. Whether he
was living in Miami or Tokyo, David tried to spend every Memorial Day doing
what he believed was his duty: remembering the dead and what they had
sacrificed so he could stand that day, sweaty but free, in their collective,
remembered presence.

David had sacrificed to be there, also. Two tours of duty in Vietnam as an
aircraft carrier-based medic meant that he and his crew mates were always in
danger whenever they helicoptered to rescue downed pilots on land or sea. The
high-risk escapades also gave him a saucy, lifelong swagger.

The war and its divisive effects on the U.S. never left him. In fact, he left
the U.S. and lived in Japan for nearly 20 years because of it. Japan brought
him peace, a family and a career as an international trade consultant. The
most lucrative, far-reaching American contacts he made were in the-then
exploding U.S.-Asia grain trade. Investment money and U.S. ag exports were
flooding Japan and South Korea and were about to get a toehold in China, and
David was smack in the middle of it all.

He returned to America in the late 1980s when the grain giants expanded into
ethanol, fructose, and several never-heard-of-before biotech processes to
"engineer" new items like lysine, a livestock feed supplement, and citric
acid, a food additive.

Then, in 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice announced it was investigating
Archer Daniels Midland for allegedly fixing prices in some of its markets.
Even more incredible, the DOJ confirmed that its evidence included video and
audio tapes made by an ADM insider, an executive named Mark Whitacre.

Whitacre had two weaknesses no corporate mole should possess: He couldn't stop
talking and his best friend in the grain trade was David. Whatever Whitacre
knew or learned, David soon would know or learn.

And, soon thereafter, David's contacts at the New York Times, Washington Post,
Chicago Tribune and other outlets would know.

The ADM story, however, was a saga of power and corruption that claimed the
careers of both ADM executives who lived it and journalists who covered it
because the truth was often hidden in a haystack of lies.

One of its biggest victims was David. He felt that the Justice Department had
intentionally botched an even bigger case against ADM because of the company's
political connections, and he sank into a sea of bitterness and paranoia. The
last time my family visited him before his 2015 death, I spotted a sawed-off,
12-gauge shotgun painted to match the living room wall it was leaning against
making it - in plain sight - all but invisible.

Why? I asked.

"Because," he said, "you never know."

Maybe not, but I do know that when his fear and anger at individuals replaced
his love and duty for his nation, this honorable lion became a gun-hiding
mouse. It was a tragic unwinding; one that no one would wish on anyone or any
friend. Or any nation.

More information: [www.farmandfoodfile.com](http://www.farmandfoodfile.com).

title: A friend who was so much more
html:
Every Memorial Day, my longtime friend David would honor both his family and fellow Vietnam War veterans with a visit to his hometown cemetery, an hour's drive west of St. Louis.

With the help of siblings and cousins, David would mow the grass in the family plot, scrub its granite and brass grave markers, and place colorful, fist-sized peonies on the graves of those he knew and those he didn't. Whether he was living in Miami or Tokyo, David tried to spend every Memorial Day doing what he believed was his duty: remembering the dead and what they had sacrificed so he could stand that day, sweaty but free, in their collective, remembered presence.

David had sacrificed to be there, also. Two tours of duty in Vietnam as an aircraft carrier-based medic meant that he and his crew mates were always in danger whenever they helicoptered to rescue downed pilots on land or sea. The high-risk escapades also gave him a saucy, lifelong swagger.

The war and its divisive effects on the U.S. never left him. In fact, he left the U.S. and lived in Japan for nearly 20 years because of it. Japan brought him peace, a family and a career as an international trade consultant. The most lucrative, far-reaching American contacts he made were in the-then exploding U.S.-Asia grain trade. Investment money and U.S. ag exports were flooding Japan and South Korea and were about to get a toehold in China, and David was smack in the middle of it all.

He returned to America in the late 1980s when the grain giants expanded into ethanol, fructose, and several never-heard-of-before biotech processes to "engineer" new items like lysine, a livestock feed supplement, and citric acid, a food additive.

Then, in 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice announced it was investigating Archer Daniels Midland for allegedly fixing prices in some of its markets. Even more incredible, the DOJ confirmed that its evidence included video and audio tapes made by an ADM insider, an executive named Mark Whitacre.

Whitacre had two weaknesses no corporate mole should possess: He couldn't stop talking and his best friend in the grain trade was David. Whatever Whitacre knew or learned, David soon would know or learn.

And, soon thereafter, David's contacts at the New York Times, Washington Post, Chicago Tribune and other outlets would know.

The ADM story, however, was a saga of power and corruption that claimed the careers of both ADM executives who lived it and journalists who covered it because the truth was often hidden in a haystack of lies.

One of its biggest victims was David. He felt that the Justice Department had intentionally botched an even bigger case against ADM because of the company's political connections, and he sank into a sea of bitterness and paranoia. The last time my family visited him before his 2015 death, I spotted a sawed-off, 12-gauge shotgun painted to match the living room wall it was leaning against making it - in plain sight - all but invisible.

Why? I asked.

"Because," he said, "you never know."

Maybe not, but I do know that when his fear and anger at individuals replaced his love and duty for his nation, this honorable lion became a gun-hiding mouse. It was a tragic unwinding; one that no one would wish on anyone or any friend. Or any nation.

More information: www.farmandfoodfile.com.
